Dear Dr. Smith,

I hope you’re well. I’m writing to share our most recent synthesis of passenger feedback regarding public-space design within transport hubs. Key themes are outlined below:

1. Heightened Stress at Security Checkpoints
   • Long queues and intrusive procedures remain dominant stressors.
   • Passengers consistently ask for clearer way-finding signage and friendlier, more empathetic staff interactions.

2. Desire for Privacy and Dignity
   • Screening areas that allow a degree of personal space and reduce the feeling of being “on display” were viewed far more favourably.
   • Small architectural tweaks—e.g., staggered lines, partial privacy screens—showed measurable improvements in perceived fairness and comfort.

3. Safety Concerns in Auxiliary Spaces
   • Restrooms and other lightly monitored zones were repeatedly cited as areas where travellers feel vulnerable, especially when travelling with children.
   • Respondents recommended better lighting, clearer sightlines, and occasional staff presence to reinforce a sense of security.

4. Calming Design Elements
   • Simple environmental cues—subtle lighting, natural materials, ambient soundscapes—helped lower reported anxiety levels by up to 18 % in our pilot mock-ups.

5. Holistic, Human-Centred Approach
   • Passengers view the journey as an integrated experience; improvements in one touch-point can be undermined if adjacent spaces lag behind.
   • A unified design language that guides travellers from curb to gate was identified as a top strategic opportunity.

Next Steps
• We are mapping these insights onto specific design interventions and will circulate a visual concept board next week.
• In parallel, we’re quantifying the potential impact on dwell time, revenue per passenger, and CSAT to strengthen the business case.

Please let me know if you’d like a deeper dive into any of the themes above or have additional dimensions you’d like us to explore.

Best regards,
[Your Name]
